item.title: Mothers who regret having children are speaking out
item.description:
At first glance, Amy* is like many busy young moms‚Äîshe‚Äôs 34, lives in Alberta, works full-time and is devoted to her five-year-old. ‚ÄúI love my son with all my heart,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúMy life revolves around this child.‚Äù Four nights a week from May to June are spent at a sports field, she says. ‚ÄúAll his schoolmates do it, so if he doesn‚Äôt, he‚Äôs left out.‚Äù

When discussing motherhood, however, Amy deviates from the maternal script: if she could make that choice over again, she says, she wouldn‚Äôt. She never wanted children (‚ÄúI was very independent,‚Äù she says)‚Äîher husband did. ‚ÄúIt would have been a deal-breaker.‚Äù Parenthood put an untenable strain on the marriage; her husband wasn‚Äôt as involved as she wanted; they separated. Life is difficult, Amy reports: ‚ÄúOur child has two homes and I‚Äôm still doing 90 per cent of it on my own.‚Äù

Amy‚Äôs candour is part of a growing yet contentious conversation about parental regret, one primarily focused on mothers. Social media provides one hub, from the 9,000-member Facebook group ‚ÄúI regret having children‚Äù (on which ‚ÄúWarren Chansky‚Äù posted: ‚ÄúI hated being a father and I don‚Äôt like the people my kids have become‚Äù) to a Facebook community with more than 2,600 members founded by Lauren Byrne, a 32-year-old ER nurse and mother of two who lives in Newfoundland. Byrne doesn‚Äôt regret having children, she tells Maclean‚Äôs, though women on the site say they do.

Byrne‚Äôs group is private and carefully monitored, a necessity given the criticism and judgment admitting regret can provoke. French psychotherapist Corinne Maier stoked an international firestorm and condemnation in 2008 with her manifesto No Kids: 40 Good Reasons Not to Have Children; her two children left her ‚Äúexhausted and bankrupt,‚Äù and she couldn‚Äôt wait for them to leave home, she wrote. In 2013, Isabella Dutton, a 57-year-old British mother of two grown children created furor with a Daily Mail essay headlined: ‚ÄúThe mother who says having these two children is the biggest regret of her life.‚Äù By 2018, however, Dutton and Maier are no longer freakish outliers; parental regret, or ‚Äúthe last parenting taboo‚Äù as it‚Äôs dubbed in the media has been covered by everyone from the BBC (‚Äú100 Women 2016: Parents who regret having children‚Äù) to Marie Claire (‚ÄúInside the growing movement of women who wished they never had kids‚Äù) to Today‚Äôs Parent (‚ÄúRegretting motherhood: What have I done with my life?‚Äù by Lola Augustine Brown, a 41-year-old mother of three aged from two to 10 who lives in rural Nova Scotia).

The discussion has been stoked by the first scholarship on regret; Israeli sociologist Orna Donath thrust it into the spotlight with her 2015 book Regretting Motherhood: A Study, based on interviews with 23 Israeli women, all anonymous, aged 26 to 73, five of them grandmothers.

Unsurprisingly, women who express regret are called selfish, unnatural, abusive ‚Äúbad moms‚Äù or believed to ‚Äúexemplify the ‚Äòwhining‚Äô culture we allegedly live in,‚Äù as Donath puts it. One commenter called Dutton ‚Äúan utterly miserable, cold-hearted and selfish woman.‚Äù Even Donath has been savaged for her research: one critic suggested she be burned alive.

Discussing maternal regret raises ethical dilemmas but is necessary, says Andrea O‚ÄôReilly, a professor at York University‚Äôs School of Gender, Sexuality and Women‚Äôs Studies and the author of 18 books on motherhood: ‚ÄúI understand the protection of children, but if you completely enforce that you have no mother voices telling their story, and you don‚Äôt want that either.‚Äù

Jessica Alba‚Äôs airbrushed family life glosses over the reality of mothering for many women. @jessicaalba/Instagram

And what we‚Äôre learning about regretful mothers upends binary thinking that women who regret having children must be neglectful or substandard parents: it‚Äôs motherhood these women regret, not the children. Dutton expressed love for her offspring (‚ÄúI would cut off my arm if either needed it‚Äù); it was maternal strictures she bristled against (‚ÄúI felt oppressed by my constant responsibility for them‚Äù). In Today‚Äôs Parent, Augustine Brown called her children ‚Äúthe best things I have ever done‚Äù and assured readers she wasn‚Äôt ‚Äúa monster‚Äù before expressing conflicted feelings: ‚ÄúWhat I‚Äôm struggling with is that it feels like their amazing life comes at the expense of my own,‚Äù she wrote, expressing remorse for ‚Äúthis life I wanted so badly and now find myself trapped in.‚Äù

Feeling trapped or suffocated is a common theme in Donath‚Äôs work; mothers felt ‚Äúas if the metaphorical umbilical cord binding them to their children were in fact wrapped around their neck.‚Äù Many women said they felt pressured to have children. So did German novelist Sarah Fischer, author of Die Muttergl√ºck-L√ºge (The Myth of Mothering Joy: Regretting Motherhood‚ÄîWhy I‚Äôd Rather Have Become a Father), published in 2016, who writes she knew she‚Äôd made a mistake ‚Äúwhen the contractions started.‚Äù

The premise that motherhood is not a one-size-fits-all role shouldn‚Äôt come as a surprise in 2018, given the rise of the ‚Äúchildless by choice‚Äù movement or an international decline in birth rates. Still, it‚Äôs received as an affront to the ‚Äúsanctity‚Äù of motherhood and the entrenched belief that the maternal instinct is innate and unconditional‚Äîdespite ample historical evidence to the contrary.

German novelist Sarah Fischer, author of The Myth of Mothering Joy. Frank Bauer

In pushing the boundaries of accepted maternal response, however, something else is happening: a small group of women are reframing motherhood, an institution increasingly idealized and commodified to near-absurd ends. June Cleaver has been replaced by Jessica Alba, the former actress who runs a billion-dollar organic baby goods empire and posts Instagram images of perfect airbrushed domesticity for her millions of followers. Celebrity tabloids are fuelled by maternity mania; Beyonc√©‚Äôs 2017 Instagram post announcing twins (via a beatific photo of the performer framed by flowers, fecund belly on display) was the most shared ever on Instagram. Pressure on women to have kids is intense, says Amy. ‚ÄúI work with a lot of girls and, if they haven‚Äôt had kids, they‚Äôre told, ‚ÄòThe clock is ticking.‚Äô‚Äâ‚Äù Predictably, one of the first interview questions fielded by Prince Harry and Meghan Markle was when they‚Äôll start a family.

Simultaneously, the demanding, exhausting, self-sacrificing and often thankless work of mothering‚Äî‚Äúthe most important job a woman can have,‚Äù as Ivanka Trump put it in a 2016 campaign video‚Äîhas never been more restrictive, scrutinized and questioned. Anti-natalist philosopher David Benatar, the subject of a recent New Yorker profile, even argues no one should have children on compassionate grounds given the painfulness of life. Add to that the notion that children bring self-fulfillment or self-actualization, and it becomes a breeding ground for regret.

But mothers voicing regret also signal something else: a larger groundswell of maternal reckoning, one Augustine Brown compares to the #MeToo campaign. ‚ÄúWe still can‚Äôt talk honestly about what it‚Äôs like to live with those pressures and those sacrifices,‚Äù she tells Maclean‚Äôs. Response to her story was overwhelmingly positive, she reports, save one woman: ‚ÄúShe told me I should see a therapist and that my children deserved a better mother.‚Äù Yet dozens of women wrote to thank her for making them not feel so alone‚Äîor abnormal. Donath‚Äôs book has also been a sensation. When published in Germany (an English translation arrived in 2017), #RegrettingMotherhood trended on that country‚Äôs Twitter.

Expanding the vocabulary of motherhood helps all women, Donath tells Maclean‚Äôs: ‚ÄúWe need to make it easier for mothers to be mothers but to also rethink the policies of reproduction and the very obligation to become mothers at all.‚Äù Augustine Brown is more direct: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre angry, we‚Äôre fed up and we‚Äôre on the verge of something.‚Äù

Beyonc√©‚Äôs 2017 Instagram post announcing twins was the most liked ever on Instagram. @beyonce/Instagram

Regret requires choice. So there‚Äôs little surprise that expression of parental regret mirrors the arrival of the pill, and with it the decision to delay or even forgo reproduction. The first indication came in 1975, when advice columnist Ann Landers asked readers: ‚ÄúIf you had it to do over again, would you have children?‚Äù Of more than 10,000 responses, 70 per cent said ‚Äúno.‚Äù The few attempts to quantify parental regret since have shown mixed results. A 2002-03 study by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services found that three per cent of parents disagreed with the statement: ‚ÄúThe rewards of being a parent are worth it despite the cost and the work it takes.‚Äù A 2016 German study found eight per cent of 1,200 parents polled said they would choose not to have children again.

Traditionally, regret has been viewed as the purview of the childless. Thomas Gilovich‚Äîa Cornell University psychologist famed for research that indicates people are far more likely to regret things they haven‚Äôt done than things they have‚Äîexamined people with high IQs: not one regretted having children; several reported regretting not having a family. That assumption has been challenged, however, by the ‚Äúchildless by choice‚Äù movement and research debunking the myth that babies have a bonding effect on marriage or that children bring happiness: a 2010 American Sociological Association study found that parents were more likely to be depressed than their child-free counterparts, and that people without kids were happier than any other group.

Follow Maclean‚Äôs on Facebook ¬ª Subscribe to our Newsletters ¬ª

The notion that motherhood is a sacred role rather than one of the most profound and complex human relationships has made it somehow magically exempt from regret, Donath tells Maclean‚Äôs. In every other realm where regret is experienced, people soldier on, she notes. Her research even indicates that women who feel guilt over regret are more conscientious parents. ‚ÄúThe more I feel [regret], the more I give them,‚Äù a mother interviewed by Donath said about her two children.

Donath views suspicion over the existence of maternal regret as consistent with a traditional rejection of women expressing negative responses to motherhood, pointing to the reluctance to accept post-partum depression until the late 20th century; before then, mothers reporting perinatal sadness were dismissed as ‚Äúneurotic.‚Äù

Regret differs from more common ambivalence, Donath says: ‚ÄúThere are mothers who experience ambivalent feelings but do not regret becoming mothers, and there are mothers who regret becoming mothers and are not ambivalent about motherhood.‚Äù Conflating the two precludes listening to mothers who lament having given birth: ‚ÄúIf we rush into talking about the hardships of motherhood only, then we empty regret of any content and neutralize any ability to examine the axiom that motherhood is necessarily experienced as worthwhile by all mothers everywhere.‚Äù

Parental regret also highlights gendered asymmetry around parenting; while fathers are increasingly active in child-raising, most child care and housework is still performed by women, as 2017 StatsCan census data indicates. Donath has also interviewed men who regret fatherhood, and has found one difference is that most men who became fathers even though they didn‚Äôt want to did so because their partner wanted to be a mother, and they didn‚Äôt want to live without her. ‚ÄúThey made their decisions without being threatened by divorce, as opposed to several women in my study.‚Äù Stephen Marche, author of The Unmade Bed: The Messy Truth About Men and Women in the 21st Century, often writes about fatherhood. He says he has never met a father willing to admit to regret: ‚ÄúI can think of only a few who might even have felt it,‚Äù he says. Fathers‚Äô regret tends to be expressed with their feet, says York University‚Äôs O‚ÄôReilly. ‚ÄúThey walk away.‚Äù While men are judged for doing so, they don‚Äôt face the same censure as women, she says: ‚ÄúMen‚Äôs identity is never collapsed into their parental one; if you‚Äôre a bad mother, you‚Äôre a bad woman. If a father is late at daycare, it‚Äôs ‚ÄòPoor thing, he‚Äôs busy.‚Äô A mother who‚Äôs late is viewed as selfish and irresponsible.‚Äù That‚Äôs changing, O‚ÄôReilly believes, though she questions the extent: ‚ÄúSome men may feel their children are central to their identity but I‚Äôve never seen it.‚Äù

Exacerbating gendered parenting imbalances is the fact that, as mothers entered the workforce in record numbers in the 1970s, parenting philosophies increasingly embraced hovering attachment. ‚ÄúHelicopter parent‚Äù was coined in the 1960s; ‚Äúattachment parenting‚Äù was introduced in 1992 by evangelical physician William Sears based on three tenets‚Äîbreastfeeding (sometimes into toddlerhood), co-sleeping and carrying babies close in slings. Once regarded as fringe, it‚Äôs now the dominant parenting mode among white, middle-class, educated women, says O‚ÄôReilly. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like a cult.‚Äù

Time spent by parents with their kids has doubled in four decades, The Economist revealed in November; in an analysis of 11 wealthy countries, mothers spent an average of 104 minutes a day caring for children in 2012, up from 54 in 1965. Men do less, but far more than they did in the past: 59 minutes a day, up from 16.

Parenting standards have become ‚Äúfar more draconian‚Äù since O‚ÄôReilly raised her kids in the ‚Äô80s and ‚Äô90s, she says, pointing to a confluence of forces‚Äîthe rise of materialism, consumerism, neoliberalism and social media‚Äîturning parenthood into a performance. Parents now raise children in a far more difficult, competitive world and are pressured to do more with far less, she says: ‚ÄúExpectations have been ramped up to such a point that standards are impossible to achieve.‚Äù

Declining fertility rates and older, more educated first-time mothers have also contributed to heightened expectations. The fertility rate in Canada has dropped from 2.1‚Äîthe replacement level needed for the population to renew itself without immigration‚Äîin 1971 to 1.6 in 2016. Older mothers are used to autonomy. But children don‚Äôt go as planned, she says: ‚ÄúSo much of motherhood is very much out of your control.‚Äù

French Writer Corinne Maier, author of No Kids: 40 Good Reasons Not to Have Children. Magali Delporte

O‚ÄôReilly points to another dramatic change: Where in the ‚Äô70s maternal control was structural, dictated from the outside, now it‚Äôs ideological, with women becoming their own gatekeepers. ‚ÄúI hear women say, ‚ÄòI have to quit my job because Johnny needs me 24/7.‚Äô Or, ‚ÄòOf course I have to share my bed.‚Äô Or, ‚ÄòOf course I have to breastfeed until he‚Äôs five.‚Äô It‚Äôs more insidious.‚Äù The proliferation of mommy blogs has also introduced the terms ‚Äúsanctimommies‚Äù and ceaseless ‚Äúmommy wars‚Äù (breast vs. bottle, co-sleeping vs. sleep-training, stay at home vs. working outside the home) that somehow pits woman against woman as opposed to confronting the controlling institution of motherhood itself, as outlined in Adrienne Rich‚Äôs landmark 1976 book Of Women Born: Motherhood as Experience and Institution.

The rise of ‚Äúintensive mothering‚Äù has political implications; as Susan Douglas and Meredith Michaels wrote in their 2005 book The Mommy Myth: The Idealization of Motherhood and How It Has Undermined All Women, an increasingly powerful conservative subculture is determined to ‚Äúre-domesticate the women of America through motherhood.‚Äù The words are prescient given the arrival of a U.S. administration that has imbued The Handmaid‚Äôs Tale with chilling relevance. Declining birth rates have also seen a surge in pro-natalism. In December, House Speaker Paul Ryan instructed women in the U.S.‚Äîwhere birth rates are at an all-time low‚Äîto have more children to ensure the future of Social Security and Medicaid benefits.

In No Kids, Maier‚Äôs depiction of parenthood as ‚Äúan inward-looking prison focused on the child‚Äù was also intended as a rebuke to pro-fertility politics in France. And these, she noted, have far less to do with love of children than ‚Äúa form of nationalism to enhance our identity.‚Äù Pro-natalism serves national interests, says Donath, hence messaging that motherhood is a matter of nature only‚Äî‚Äúthat it is natural for women to want to be mothers because they are females; that it is natural that any woman who is considered to be physically and emotionally healthy would know what to do after the child was born (‚Äòmaternal instinct‚Äô); and that it is natural that any woman would evaluate motherhood as a worthwhile change in her life since this is the essence of her existence because she is a female.‚Äù

There‚Äôs an inherent paradox, Donath points out: Women are told they instinctively possess the tools to mother well while constantly being told how to conduct relationships with their children to be ‚Äúgood women‚Äù and ‚Äúgood mothers.‚Äù And that has come to mean child before all, as seen when author Ayelet Waldman famously received hate mail after stating in the New York Times in 2005 that she loved her husband more than her children; she parlayed the outrage into a 2012 book, Bad Mother: A Chronicle of Maternal Crimes, Minor Calamities, and Occasional Moments of Grace. The belief that women are uniquely equipped to parent also marginalizes fathers: author Rahna Reiko Rizzuto was publicly shamed when she revealed she preferred not to be a full-time parent in her memoir, Hiroshima in the Morning. Now a non-custodial mother to two young sons, she has reported being ‚Äúthreatened with death and sexual violence by strangers.‚Äù

Taboos surrounding discussing maternal regret have made studying it difficult, says O‚ÄôReilly. The late feminist philosopher Sara Ruddick, author of Maternal Thinking, tried to publish a book on the topic, with contributions from scholars who were mothers, but had to shelve it. ‚ÄúWomen didn‚Äôt want to out themselves,‚Äù says O‚ÄôReilly. ‚ÄúThey were saying, ‚ÄòWhat if my child ever read this?‚Äô They became irrational; these are scholars who had written on challenging topics.‚Äù

Even fictional mothers expressing regret are controversial, O‚ÄôReilly notes, pointing to We Need to Talk About Kevin, Lionel Shriver‚Äôs acclaimed 2003 novel told from the point of view of a mother whose son went on a murderous rampage. Yet the mothers of children who kill don‚Äôt express regret, O‚ÄôReilly notes, pointing to the memoirs A Mother‚Äôs Reckoning: Living in the Aftermath of Tragedy by Sue Klebold, mother of Dylan Klebold, one of the two boys who killed 13 at Columbine High School, and Aftermath by Monique L√©pine, mother of Marc, who murdered 14 women at Montreal‚Äôs √âcole Polytechnique in 1989. ‚ÄúThese are mothers who, if anyone, should feel regret,‚Äù says O‚ÄôReilly. ‚ÄúBut Klebold writes that she has no regret‚Äîthough she blames herself for not seeing the signs. It‚Äôs regret for what happened, not that she had a son.‚Äù

Women who express regret, or any critique of motherhood, typically have done so through humour, O‚ÄôReilly says, pointing to the explosion of parenting memoirs with titles like The Three-Martini Playdate, a joke that hinges on tacit acceptance that motherhood requires medication‚Äîfrom Valium, ‚Äúmother‚Äôs little helper‚Äù in the ‚Äô60s, to wine, or ‚Äúliquid patience,‚Äù today. Such a lighthearted approach only works when children are young, she says. As they get older, problems become serious‚Äîanorexia, addiction. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt contain them with humour.‚Äù

Yet almost all writing about motherhood focuses on accounts of mothers of babies and toddlers, Donath says. There‚Äôs a lack of retrospective accounts from mothers of older children, which is why hearing from grandmothers is important. These mothers can afford to be more truthful, says O‚ÄôReilly. ‚ÄúMothers of younger children don‚Äôt want to jinx it.‚Äù

Pop singer Pink has been declared a ‚Äúmom crush‚Äù for her slightly less curated depiction of mothering. @pink/Instagram

Yet that too is changing, as mothers are showing their anger. In The Myth of Mothering Joy, Fischer, mother of a young daughter, paints an unsparing picture: ‚ÄúThe reality of motherhood is incontinence, boredom, weight gain, saggy breasts, depression, the end of romance, lack of sleep, dumbing down, career downturn, loss of sex drive, poverty, exhaustion and lack of fulfillment.‚Äù

Such accounts highlight the sacrifices required to parent‚Äîand that self-fulfillment often isn‚Äôt anywhere on the menu. There‚Äôs clearly an audience eager for a more realistic portrayal of mothering, an antidote to what one mother calls ‚Äúthe perfect Pinterest mom.‚Äù The singer Pink has been declared a ‚Äúmom crush‚Äù for her unvarnished, if still curated, depiction of mothering on Instagram; in December, the singer recounted on Twitter that a mother approached her to tell her: ‚Äúshe got strength from my parenting ‚Äôcause I‚Äôm not afraid to f--k up in public.‚Äù Popular entertainment has embraced the ‚Äúbad mom‚Äù‚Äîa.k.a. the anti-‚Äúgood mom,‚Äù seen in the Bad Moms film franchise and SMILF, a new Showtime series about a financially strapped, loving but sometimes selfish single mom.

Lauren Byrne can also be counted among those mothers who reject the idealized script, and with it the silencing of mothers. That‚Äôs why she set up her Facebook page, she says: ‚ÄúEveryone was talking about how fantastic it was. And I was, ‚ÄòWho are you people?‚Äô I‚Äôm exhausted.‚Äù When she announced wanting to stop breastfeeding at nine months because her child was biting her, she was attacked. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt believe the negativity. People said, ‚ÄòFormula is poison.‚Äô I needed a place to say, ‚ÄòYes, I love my baby, but this sucks.‚Äô‚Äâ‚Äù Even saying you want time away from your kids is verboten, Byrne says. ‚ÄúPeople say, ‚ÄòYou shouldn‚Äôt say that. They‚Äôre blessings. You should feel lucky.‚Äô But it‚Äôs not unicorns and rainbows all the time. But women can‚Äôt complain that ‚Äòthis is really hard‚Äô because people think you‚Äôre a bad mom.‚Äù

Byrne has experienced maternal regret in a limited way, she says: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt regret my children but I regret the timing of my children.‚Äù Her first pregnancy, when she was 24 and newly married, was unplanned: ‚ÄúEveryone was partying and still drinking and I was home, 50 lb. heavier than I was used to being, with the baby on my boob for hours, thinking, ‚ÄòHow did this happen?‚Äô‚Äâ‚Äù

Victoria Elder and Morgane, her 18-year-old daughter. Daymon Gardner

Difficulties faced by mothers remain submerged, Byrne believes: ‚ÄúSo many mothers are on anti-anxiety medication and antidepressants or have secret post-partum lasting for years.‚Äù Silencing can allow systems to go unchecked, mothers ignored. Angela*, who lives in Newfoundland, went for months with debilitating undiagnosed post-partum after the premature birth of twins. She felt cheated, she told Maclean‚Äôs, when she didn‚Äôt experience the instant bond she was told mothers are supposed to have. ‚ÄúI felt I had been robbed.‚Äù She wasn‚Äôt prepared for the difficulties: ‚ÄúEveryone talks about motherhood like it‚Äôs this wonderful thing and you‚Äôre going to love those children the second they come out,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúNobody talks about how hard having children can be, how exhaustion can affect you and how sometimes love has to be developed.‚Äù She doesn‚Äôt feel she can be candid, even with health professionals.

Yet brutal candour is required, says Augustine Brown, if mothers are ever to be seen as independent of their children. And this is where the subject of regret introduces a radical new twist in the mother plot: It introduces the notion that mothers can exist autonomously from their children.

Augustine Brown says she‚Äôs candid with her children, telling them that being a mother is not the most important aspect of her life. ‚ÄúThey know it ties with my work and who I am,‚Äù she says. They also know she enjoys her time away when she travels for work. ‚ÄúThey cry when I leave but I feel it‚Äôs important for them to know they‚Äôre not the centre of the world.‚Äù Slowly, we‚Äôre also hearing from those assumed to be the victims of parental regret: the children of women who voice it. Last year, the Guardian profiled Victoria Elder, who posted about her feelings of maternal regret on the online question-and-answer site Quora (‚ÄúI felt like, and still feel like, I made a mistake,‚Äù she wrote). Elder‚Äôs 18-year-old daughter, Morgane, told the paper her mother shared the post with her first. She has no doubt her mother loves her, she said: ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs always been there.‚Äù She also expressed anger at the criticism her mother endured: ‚ÄúThere were a bunch of people calling her a liar and a horrible mum, which really made me upset, because I know what she‚Äôs really like.‚Äù

Donath predicts discussion of maternal regret will remain polarized‚Äî‚Äúbetween rage and denying its existence, and acknowledging its significance and its social meanings‚Äù‚Äîeven as more women come forward. There‚Äôs no catharsis, no happy ending, of the sort expected from women, she says. Recognizing regret as part of the maternal experience requires a sea change in thinking: that ‚Äúmothers are owners of their bodies, thoughts, emotions, imagination and memories‚Äîand are capable of acknowledging whether all of this was worthwhile or not.‚Äù And that may be regretful mothers‚Äô most lasting legacy of all.

* Requested that only her first name be used.

item.title: Social Media: Making Us Dumber?
item.description:
That‚Äôs because the pernicious social dynamics of these online spaces hammer home the idea that anyone who disagrees with you on any controversial subject, even a little bit, is incorrigibly dumb or evil or suspect. On a wide and expanding range of issues, there‚Äôs no such thing as good-faith disagreement.

The online anger aimed at Mr. Pinker provides a perfect case study.

The clip was deeply misleading. If you watch the whole eight-minute video from which it was culled, it‚Äôs clear that Mr. Pinker‚Äôs entire point is that the alt-right‚Äôs beliefs are false and illogical ‚Äî but that the left needs to do a better job fighting against them.

The clip begins with Mr. Pinker saying he agrees with the other panelists (two journalists and a lawyer) that ‚Äúpolitical correctness has done an enormous amount of harm in the sliver of the population that might be ‚Äî I wouldn‚Äôt want to say ‚Äòpersuadable,‚Äô but certainly whose affiliation might be up for grabs.‚Äù This problem presents itself when it comes to ‚Äúthe often highly literate, highly intelligent people who gravitate to the alt-right: internet savvy, media savvy, who often are radicalized in that way, who ‚Äòswallow the red pill,‚Äô as the saying goes, the allusion from ‚ÄòThe Matrix.‚Äô‚Äù

Mr. Pinker goes on to argue that when members of this group encounter, for the first time, ideas that he believes to be frowned upon or suppressed in liberal circles ‚Äî that most suicide bombers are Muslim or that members of different racial groups commit crimes at different rates ‚Äî they are ‚Äúimmediately infected with both the feeling of outrage that these truths are unsayable‚Äù and are provided with ‚Äúno defense against taking them to what we might consider to be rather repellent conclusions.‚Äù

That‚Äôs unfortunate, Mr. Pinker argues, because while someone might use these facts to support bigoted views, that needn‚Äôt be the case, because ‚Äúfor each one of these facts, there are very powerful counterarguments for why they don‚Äôt license racism and sexism and anarcho-capitalism and so on.‚Äù

He then goes on to carefully explain those counterarguments: For example, while at the moment it‚Äôs true that, according to the Bureau of Justice Statistics, the homicide rate is higher for blacks than for whites, that doesn‚Äôt really tell us anything about a group of people since at different times in history, different groups have had elevated crime rates ‚Äî at one point Irish-Americans did. By that same token, he says, ‚Äúthe majority of domestic terrorism is committed by right-wing extremist groups,‚Äù not Muslims.

It would be impossible for a reasonable person to watch the eight-minute video and come away thinking Mr. Pinker‚Äôs point is to praise the alt-right rather than to make a psychological argument about political correctness, alt-right recruitment and how to better fight that movement‚Äôs bigoted ideas

Continue reading the main story

Now, maybe you disagree with certain parts of this argument ‚Äî I do, in that I think Mr. Pinker overstates the intensity of campus political correctness ‚Äî but it‚Äôs hard to have that debate in the first place when such a wildly skewed version of Mr. Pinker‚Äôs point is spreading like wildfire on the internet.

Steven Pinker will be O.K. A fleeting Twitter blowup isn‚Äôt going to bruise his long and successful career as a public intellectual. But this is happening more and more ‚Äî and in many cases to people who don‚Äôt have the standing and reputation he does.

It‚Äôs getting harder and harder to talk about anything controversial online without every single utterance of an opinion immediately being caricatured by opportunistic outrage-mongers, at which point everyone, afraid to be caught exposed in the skirmish that‚Äôs about to break out, rushes for the safety of their ideological battlements, where they can safely scream out their righteousness in unison. In this case: ‚ÄúSteven Pinker said the alt-right is good! But the alt-right is bad! We must defend this principle!‚Äù

This is making us dumber.

item.title: New DHS policy on demands for passwords to travelers‚Äô electronic devices
item.description:
US Customs and Border Protection, a component of the Department of Homeland Security, today posted a revised policy on Border Searches of Electronic Devices¬†and a¬†Privacy Impact Assessment of some of the changes made by the new policy.

CBP has received (and largely ignored) numerous complaints by travelers who have been detained and told they wouldn‚Äôt be allowed to go unless they told CBP the passwords to their smartphones, laptop computers, or other electronic devices. Electronic devices have been seized and copied, and in some cases returned only long afterward and/or in altered or damaged condition. A lawsuit challenging suspicionless searches and seizures of data stored on travelers‚Äô electronic devices, brought by EFF and the ACLU, is pending in Boston.

Federal courts have generally been overly deferential to government claims to the existence of a general exception to the Fourth Amendment making it per se ‚Äúreasonable‚Äù to search or seize anything at or ‚Äúnear‚Äù a border or at an international airport, regardless of whether there is any basis to suspect a traveler of anything except international travel.

But the new CBP policy stretches the government‚Äôs claim of authority for warrantless, suspicionless, searches and seizures of electronic devices and data even further than its 2009 predecessor.

As the new PIA correctly notes, ‚ÄúThe 2009 policy was silent regarding CBP‚Äôs handling of passcode-protected or encrypted information.‚Äù

CBP now says as follows, without citing any basis for this assertion:

Travelers are obligated to present electronic devices and the information contained therein in a condition that allows inspection of the device and its contents‚Ä¶ Passcodes or other means of entry may be requested and retained as needed to facilitate the examination of an electronic device or information contained on an electronic device, including information on the device that is accessible through software applications present on the device. If an Officer is unable to complate an inspection of an electronic device because it is protected by a passcode or encryption, the Officer may‚Ä¶ detain the device pending a determination as to its admissibility, exclusion, or other disposition.

In other words, CBP is now claiming the authority to confiscate your cellphones, laptops, memory cards, and any other electronic devices if you won‚Äôt tell CBP your passwords, and to retain the passwords you give them as well as the contents of those devices.

Yes, this applies to U.S. citizens and permanent residents as well as visitors.

The PIA admits that, as a general ‚ÄúPrinciple of Purpose Specification‚Äù for fair information practices, ‚ÄúDHS should specifically articulate the authority which permits the collection of PII [Personally Identifiable Information] and specifically articulate the purpose or purposes for which the PII is intended to be used.‚Äù

But the DHS dismisses these concerns: ‚ÄúThere is no privacy risk to purpose specification. The legal precedent is clear, and all information is maintained, stored, and disseminated consistent with published systems of records notices.‚Äù

The claim about this all being consistent with published notices sounds plausible and perhaps reassuring ‚Äî until you look at the notices in question. CBP says that passwords for electronic devices, and images of data extracted from electronic devices, will be stored¬† in the Automated Targeting System (ATS). But there‚Äôs no mention of passwords or device images in the most recent (or any previous) system of records notice (SORN) for ATS. Nor is there any ‚Äúcatch-all‚Äù category in that SORN that would appear to include this data.

Even if the public had been given proper notice, the Privacy Act permits the collection of information about how individuals exercise rights protected by the First Amendment only if this has been explicitly authorized by Federal law. No Federal statute mentions the collection by CBP or DHS of passwords for, or data from, travelers‚Äô electronic devices.

Pursuant to the Privacy Act, it‚Äôs a crime for a federal agency or official to maintain a system of records without having first published a SORN¬† giving notice of all of the categories of information included in the syatem. If CBP officials have been storing passwords to travelers electronic devices, or data obtained from those devices, in ATS, any CBP agents responsible for those actions are criminals.

We won‚Äôt hold our breath waiting for these CBP officers to be prosecuted, but travelers shouldn‚Äôt think that any of this is within what is allowed by existing laws and court precedents, much less what should be allowed by the First and Fourth Amendments to the Constitution.

What should you do if officers of CBP or other DHS components ask you for the password to your electronic device or want to confiscate it or copy data from it?

First, don‚Äôt disclose your password(s) and don‚Äôt consent to any search or seizure. Telling an officer your password might be construed as giving them permission to use that password to make a complete copy of all of the data on your device.¬† Police at borders or elsewhere have the legal authority to conduct some searches without your consent, but you are never required to consent. That‚Äôs what ‚Äúconsent‚Äù means. If they are going to do it anyway, they will do it with or without your consent. Consenting to a search or seizure they are going to carry out anyway can only make your situation worse, not better. Make clear that if they search or seize your device or data, it will be a nonconsensual search. If you are given a receipt for your device(s) or some other form to fill out or sign, use it as a chance to put your denial of consent in writing in a way that will make be harder for them later to claim that you consented. Write, ‚ÄúI did not and I do not consent to this search or seizure.‚Äù It‚Äôs generally a bad idea to sign anything without first consulting a lawyer.

Second, if they ask you for your password or other data, ask them for the Paperwork Reduction Act notice including the ‚ÄúOMB Control Number‚Äù applicable to this collection of information. ‚ÄúWhat is the password to this device?‚Äù is a verbal collection of information, which is prohibited by the Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) unless it has been approved in advance by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB),¬† a ‚Äúcontrol number‚Äù has been assigned by OMB, and individuals from whom information is to be collected are given notice of this. Neither CBP nor DHS has ever requested or received OMB approval for collection of device passwords or images, so these agencies are forbidden by the PRA from imposing any sanctions on individuals who decline to provide this information.

Third, tell the officers if any or all of your devices contain privileged data, and invoke your rights under the Privacy Protection Act. If you intend to post some of your photos or descriptions of events on social media, your documents and digital materials are covered by the Privacy Protection Act ‚Äî but only if the officers conducting the search or seizure know that the device contains privileged information. So tell them. Consider putting a copy of this notice and copy of the law on each of your devices as a ‚ÄúREADME‚Äù file, and carrying a paper copy of at least the first page in your wallet or somewhere handy. This probably won‚Äôt stop the border cops, but it might get them to pause while they ask for higher-level approval for the search or seizure. As we‚Äôve discussed previously, there‚Äôs a partial exception to the Privacy Protection Act for some border searches, but it‚Äôs limited. And if they search or seize your device anyway, knowing that it contains material prvileged by the Privacy Protection Act, you can go after them personally for money damages.
